acacia tree.note: Acacia tree – Durable wood used in building the tabernacle and Ark of the Covenant (Exodus 25:10).

almond.note: Almond – Symbol of watchfulness and divine choice, as in Aaron’s rod that budded (Numbers 17:8; Jeremiah 1:11).

almond tree.note: Almond tree – Symbol of watchfulness and early blooming, as seen in Aaron’s budding rod (Numbers 17:8; Jeremiah 1:11).

anise.note: Anise – A spice mentioned by Jesus when criticizing legalistic tithing (Matthew 23:23, KJV).

barley.note: Barley – A staple grain, often associated with the poor and used in offerings (John 6:9; Leviticus 23:10).

bramble.note: Bramble – A thorny shrub used in Jotham’s parable to symbolize worthless leadership (Judges 9:14–15).

brier.note: Brier – A thorny plant representing judgment or obstacles in prophetic imagery (Isaiah 5:6; Ezekiel 28:24).

bulrush.note: Bulrush – A marsh plant used to make Moses’ basket and papyrus (Exodus 2:3; Isaiah 18:2).

calamus.note: Calamus – A fragrant reed used in the holy anointing oil (Exodus 30:23).

cassia.note: Cassia – A fragrant spice used in anointing oil and perfume (Psalm 45:8; Exodus 30:24).

cedar.note: Cedar – A strong, aromatic wood used in Solomon’s temple and David’s palace (1 Kings 6:9–10).

chestnut.note: Chestnut – Possibly referenced in some translations as a tree planted by water (Ezekiel 31:8, KJV).

cinnamon.note: Cinnamon – Aromatic spice included in the sacred anointing oil (Exodus 30:23).

coriander.note: Coriander – A plant whose seed resembled manna in appearance (Exodus 16:31; Numbers 11:7).

cummin.note: Cummin – An herb used in food and referenced by Jesus in teaching about tithing (Isaiah 28:25; Matthew 23:23).

cypress tree.note: Cypress tree – A valued wood used in temple construction and associated with strength (Isaiah 44:14).

fig tree.note: Fig tree – Represents peace, prosperity, and spiritual fruitfulness (Micah 4:4; Matthew 21:19).

figs.note: Figs – A common biblical fruit, symbolizing peace and security (1 Kings 4:25; Mark 11:13–14).

fir.note: Fir – Mentioned in translations as a tree used in temple construction and symbolic of strength (1 Kings 5:8–10; Isaiah 60:13).

grapes.note: Grapes – Used for wine, symbolizing joy and abundance; central in communion symbolism (John 15:1–5; Matthew 26:29).

hazel.note: Hazel – Mentioned as one of the rods Jacob used to influence livestock breeding (Genesis 30:37).

hyssop.note: Hyssop – Used in ceremonial cleansing and the application of Passover blood (Exodus 12:22; Psalm 51:7).

lilies.note: Lilies – Symbol of beauty and God's care, referenced in Solomon's poetry and Jesus’ teaching (Song of Songs 2:2; Matthew 6:28–29).

myrtle tree.note: Myrtle tree – A symbol of peace and restoration in prophetic visions (Isaiah 41:19; Zechariah 1:8).

oak.note: Oak – A large, strong tree often associated with altars, burial, or divine encounters (Genesis 35:8; Isaiah 6:13).

olive tree.note: Olive tree – Source of oil for anointing and lamps, symbol of peace and blessing (Psalm 52:8; Romans 11:17).

olives.note: Olives – A key agricultural product for oil, light, and anointing (Deuteronomy 8:8; Romans 11:17).

palm trees.note: Palm – Symbol of victory and rejoicing, used in festivals and Jesus’ triumphal entry (Leviticus 23:40; John 12:13).

pine.note: Pine – Sometimes translated from Hebrew words referring to temple timber or evergreen trees (Isaiah 41:19).

pistachio.note: Pistachio – One of the choice fruits carried as a gift to Egypt (Genesis 43:11).

pomegranate.note: Pomegranate – A fruit symbolizing fertility and beauty, used in temple design and priestly robes (Exodus 28:33–34).

pomegranate tree.note: Pomegranate tree – Symbol of abundance; used in priestly garments and temple decoration (Exodus 28:33–34).

poplar.note: Poplar – Mentioned among trees planted by water, possibly symbolizing spiritual prosperity (Genesis 30:37; Hosea 4:13).

spikenard.note: Spikenard – A costly perfume used to anoint Jesus before His burial (John 12:3).

sycamore.note: Sycamore – A fig-like tree common in Israel; climbed by Zacchaeus to see Jesus (Amos 7:14; Luke 19:4).

wheat.note: Wheat – A common grain symbolizing provision, harvest, and spiritual fruit (Matthew 13:24–30).

willow.note: Willow – One of the plants used in the Feast of Tabernacles (Leviticus 23:40).
